summary: This is an FBI Miami Division internal request form to the Document Conversion Laboratory (DocLab) and Special Technologies and Applications Office (STAO) for scanning, automation, and data formatting assistance regarding telephone records obtained from an address book in the Alfredo Rodriguez obstruction of justice case. The address book, seized from Epstein's former house manager, is believed to contain contact information for previously unknown underage victims of Jeffrey Epstein and his associates.

persons.name: Alfredo Rodriguez
persons.role: Former house manager and butler to Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Subject of an FBI Miami Division obstruction of justice case opened in October 2009. He attempted to sell an address book believed to contain names and numbers of additional underage victims of Epstein rather than turn it over to law enforcement.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.role: Subject of a child prostitution case
persons.context: The individual for whom Rodriguez worked. The address book in Rodriguez's possession is believed to contain contact information for additional underage victims of Epstein.

connections.description: Rodriguez was the former house manager and butler to Jeffrey Epstein.

events.title: FBI opens obstruction case against Rodriguez
events.description: Miami Division opened an obstruction of justice case against Alfredo Rodriguez.

events.title: FBI requests scanning of Epstein-related phone records
events.description: FBI Miami Division submits a request to the DocLab and STAO to scan, automate, and format telephone records obtained from an address book seized from Alfredo Rodriguez. The records are to be loaded into the Telephone Application (TA) repository.

locations: Winchester, Virginia 22602 (Federal Bureau of Investigation, 170 Marcel Drive - DocLab address)
keyFacts: Alfredo Rodriguez, Epstein's former house manager, possessed an address book believed to contain names and telephone numbers of previously unknown underage victims of Jeffrey Epstein.
Rodriguez attempted to sell this address book to an Undercover Employee (UCE) instead of surrendering it in response to federal subpoenas from pending civil litigation.

The FBI is processing telephone records from this address book, believed to belong to Epstein, his associates, or potential underage victims, for incorporation into its Bureau-wide investigative tool, the Telephone Application (TA).
The document reveals an active FBI obstruction of justice investigation into Rodriguez in October 2009, separate from the main Epstein case, focused on his attempt to profit from evidence.
The processing request highlights the scale and technological approach of the investigation, involving scanning, OCR, and data formatting for a centralized intelligence repository.
